#!/usr/bin/env bash
# I'm using a while loop to print something 10 times
myvar=1

while [ $myvar -le 10 ] 
# the above line says "while the contents of myvar is less than or equal to 10 (meaning it will stop at 11 not 10), this loop will run
do
 echo "Best School"

 #the above script adds a number to myvar each loop (with it starting at 1) with the $(()) saying that math is happening 
done

text: in the above example, a while loop can take arguments when using the "while read" format ‒ during EACH line it reads from "textfile" (which is redirected after the done command) it will take each "field" as that variable

#!/usr/bin/env bash
#this is an exercise with while loops and changing passwords
IFS=":"
while read -r USERNAME PASSWORD USER_ID GROUP_ID USER_ID_INFO HOME_DIRECTORY COMMAND
do
 echo "The user $USERNAME is part of the $GROUP_ID gang, lives in $HOME_DIRECTORY and rides $COMMAND. $USER_ID's place is protected by the passcode $PASSWORD, more info about the user here: $USER_ID_INFO"

done < /etc/passwd

backText: bash

text: this is print the /etc/passwd ‒ the wild part is, because the /etc/passwd file is so specifically formatted and because I've "set" the IFS variable to make bash interpret ":" as the delimiter (really thought I'd have to do something more than just IFS=":" but no that works) the first field that the while read loop is actually the USERNAME, which then creates the variable USERNAME and so on and so forth ‒ notice how the reading of the file has to have the correct "order" but once the variable has been created I can put it anywhere I want
